lines: Effendi, your boots carry the dust of many roads.
Coin is a loyal shield; prices are fair as honor.
Steel for the bold, salves for the wounded, and rumors for the wise.
By Saint George's lance, I've seen quieter markets.
New Antioch remembers those who pay their debts.
Sharpen your edge, temper your heart.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: Peace upon your path, traveler. New Antioch deals in wares and wisdom.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: What balm do you seek—iron for the arm, or counsel for the heart?

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: My stall is humble but honest. Blades that bite, tonics that mend, and charms to cheat despair.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: Though the scales are just, favor smiles on those who return.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: A keen edge and lighter step—swift as a hawk on the wind. I can arrange that.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: Armor is the shell; resolve is the heart. I sell the former—may God grant you the latter.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: The trenches whisper—east winds carry smoke, west winds carry saints.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: A witch shells the valley; a relic glows where three roads meet. Walk guarded.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: A pilgrim’s mark scratched in stone—follow it at dusk and you’ll see what the careful miss.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: They call her Artillery Witch. Steel fears her less than crowds do.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: If you must stand before her thunder, keep moving and do not bargain with fear.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: I am but a trader of New Antioch—sworn to fair measure, bound to quiet roads.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: Once I carried a spear. Now I carry debts and blessings. Both are heavy in their hour.

lines.speaker: Merchant
lines.text: Walk in mercy, strike in certainty. My stall will be here when the dust settles.
